Tap. Copper amber pour with a soapy cream head. Grassy and pine hop nose and taste. Smooth palate, and fuller. Some earthy malts in here. Nice.

12 ounce bottle into tulip glass, bottled on 2/18/2014. Pours moderately hazy/cloudy deep ruby red color with a 2 finger dense light khaki head with good retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Nice soapy lacing clings on the glass. Aromas of big grapefruit, tangerine, lemon zest, orange peel, floral, grass, light pine, caramel, toast, brown sugar, light chocolate, and floral/toasted earthiness. Very nice aromas with good balance and complexity of citrus hops and dark malt notes; with good strength. Taste of grapefruit, tangerine, lemon zest, orange peel, floral, grass, pine, caramel, toast, brown sugar, light chocolate, and floral/grassy earthiness. Fair amount of earthy floral/pine bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of grapefruit, tangerine, lemon zest, orange peel, floral, grass, pine, caramel, toast, light chocolate, and floral/grassy earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Very nice complexity of bright citrus/pine hop flavors with light-moderate dark/bready malt sweetness; with a crisp malt/bitterness balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Medium carbonation and body; with a smooth, crisp, and moderately sticky mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is well hidden with minimal warming present after the finish. Overall this is a very nice amber ale. Good complexity of bright citrus/floral hops and light-moderate malt balance; and very smooth and crisp to sip on. A very enjoyable offering.

12oz bottle. Dark reddish, brown in glass. Small, fast retreating head. Solid nose of fresh, green hops. All other notes here are dwarfed. Trace strands of melon must and caramel hops. Taste has a nice back-and-forth between ultra bitter and semi-sweet (mocha, flirting with toffee), ultimately finishing bitter. Tons of pine cone and melon flavors. The hops hear linger long. Nice, surprisingly creamy mouthfeel, but burping this guy up will cause slight puckering. If you like bitter, full on hop assaults, then you have a winner here.

12 ounce bottle poured into a tulip. Bottled 2/18/2014. Pours a dark amber color with two fingers of off-white head. Nice webby lacing as the head recedes. Aromas of citrus, pine, toast, biscuit, floral notes. Tasting notes of grapefruit citrus, toast, biscuit, bitter and piney hops. Medium body with a dry finish. Semi-juicy mouthfeel, medium carbonation. Nice hopped up amber.

bottle. Light hazy brown with one finger head. This seems to have a lot more in common with a black IPA than an amber. Pretty substantial sweet caramel malt base, though not at all roasty like a black IPA. Big hops that punch through the malt. Its certainly interesting, but Im not sure it totally works for me.

Bottled 2/18/14 and poured into a Sam Adams Perfect Pint on 4/17/14. $3 single, so its a reasonable price for an Evil Twin beer.

Appearance: Well. If you get the whole bottle in, say hello to a massive amount of huge floaters and some serious sediment. Very hazy color that looks like diarrhea water with all of the floaties. Nice and sustained three finger off-white soapy head. Looks rather unappealing with the color and floaters. I like the head on it though (Who doesnt like some good head!?).

Smell: Hop Flood indeed. Pure, ripe, sharp pine and grass hops with a lot of resinous smells. Some good caramel malt in there as well, but this is an amber? It really smells like an IPA to me. The only thing making me think otherwise so far is the appearance.

Taste/feel: Hm. Well. Yeah, hm... alright. I dont know. Interesting, I suppose. My immediate thought is that this beer has more bitterness than actual flavor. Theres a nice pleasant little rush of hops initially, maybe a trace of malt, and then a bitter, bitter, bitter finish. No idea what the IBUs are on this, but its gotta be high. The burps are tasting like straight up hop cones. Im not sure just why this is listed as an amber, because it really tastes nothing like an amber to me. Its hops through and through with an intense bitterness -- not much balance to speak of. Its a good beer, and an extreme one, but so is Molotov Cocktail... that beer from Evil Twin had some balance to it. The feel here is moderate all around with texture and carbonation.

All-in-all, disappointed, and probably my least favorite Evil Twin beer. The hops are bursting fresh and tasty, but wheres the malt? Going by the color of this beer and then the flavor, the amount of hops in this brew must be off the chart. Its a pretty good beer, but not what Id expect from Evil Twin (...greatness, basically).

The malt comes through a bit more as Hop Flood warms up, but its still not something Id pick up if I wanted an amber.
Bottle. Pours cloudy brown. Big head. Nose is candy sugar. Taste is very sweet. I need to find this again and try it.

12 oz bottle. Pours a dark brown color with a small biege head that has good retention. The aroma showcases ripe grapefruit and some musty melons. The taste is bitter hops forward with grapefruit and pine set in a malt base that has caramel and a bit of cocoa. The palate seems just a bit gritty and the carbonation is lively. Finishes long and bitter. overall: Decent beer.
Pours a deep amber with a creamy off white lacing head. Aroma of caramel., citrusy and herbal notes. Flavor of tea, caramel and mixed citrusy hop notes.

Bottle pour dark amber brown with lots of floaters. Nose light citrus and lots of caramel malt. Slight vegetal. Taste bitter up front, followed by minerality and malt. Mostly caramel and toffee. Hops only coming through in bitterness. Maybe a bad sample, not very enjoyable.

Very strong grapefruit aroma, dirty malt underneath. Stained deck lumber brown. Sharp bitter flavor with a resinous bathed, semi-sweet malt contrast. Like a much lighter version of the black IPAs flavor wise. A little sticky, not too carbonated, but very dry finish. The most bitter amber ale I can remember.

Pours burnt orange with a medium off white head. Aroma is citrus, resin and a touch of caramel. Taste is bittersweet with a sticky finish, more of the malts come through on taste then aroma. Medium bodied with lingering bitters.

Deep golden color, hazy, with a huge white head, lasting well. Fresh very hoppy fruity pine aroma. Good mouthfeel. Flavour is fresh and hoppy, fruity, piney, dry and bitter. Well lasting dry bitter finish.
Bottle. Dark amber color with a lasting tan head. Bright floral hop aroma. Nice floral hop flavor up front with a slight malt backbone and a bitter hop finish. Really nice beer.

12 oz. bottle just short of 4 weeks from the bottle date. Cold stored. It pours a dark amber red color with a tall, orange head. The aroma is full with dark maltiness, subtle brown sugar, pine, floral hops and mild pineapple. The flavor is very hop forward and bitter with pine and dank with strong, almost inky bitterness and enough malt sweetness to back it up. The subtle hop fruitiness melds well with the sweet, fruity malt. The finish is a bit too punishingly bitter for my tastes, but otherwise this is a fine amber that packs a big punch.
Pours a clear amber with three fingers of fluffy off white head. Aroma is grapefruit and pine. Flavor is hoppy bitterness. Caramel. Balanced. Medium bodied. Nice beer.

Sniffer at triangle wine. Good aroma grapefruit and dark roasted grain. Dark orangy brown color. Ok head and lace. Bitter flavor. Medium body, creamy mouthfeel bitter finish. Very nice big bitter brown.
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text:
Draft at Graydons Crossing - pours a deep copper , huge resinous aromas , very very unbalanced bitterness . Not really a fan . 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

The appearance has an opaque brown color with a large off-white head, and the aroma blends floral, resin, and piney hops with caramel malts. The taste is mildly bitter, mildly sour, and a touch sweet, and the palate fuses a sticky texture, medium body, average carbonation, and a long, slightly bitter finish.
12oz bottle. A nice thick white head. Dark amber color. Hop and citrus aroma. Very piney taste. A bitter aftertaste. Not bad.
Orange smell like really orange. Flavor is mostly bitterness and caramel. Its okay.
Dark red pour from draft at the Dawson. Off white head. Crazy hoppy. Bitter. Fig earth and grassy taste. Complex. Great beer. A lot going on in this

Enjoyed on tap at the mega Whole Foods in Chicago, IL. Appearance is a murky brown with a white dissipating head. Aroma of sour hops, smell is funky, almost like a hoppy yeasty smell which I'm not too much of a fan of. Taste goes down rich in a complex hop profile without being too bitter. Taste is the best part of this for sure, most easy drinking sludge I've had yet.

UPDATED: JUL 12, 2014 Just ok for me. Tried a sample on tap at Bohemian Bull. To be fair I did try it right after the Femme Fatale Brett IPA. Pours a sort of pale amber/ brown- totally transparet. Looks somewhat wimpy in the glass. Not much head or aroma. Taste is the malty/ bread you would expect with this style. Light mouthfeel Better finish than normal with an amber brown (read, some finish and balance- not all sweet). Just cant seem to get on board with this style. I should probably skip right over amber and go from Pale Ale to Porter. 
Better than I remember- on tap at Appalachian Vinter.  Like an amber with something to it- definite hop presence and decently weighted body.   Pours opaque reddish brown with decent head.   Malt and hops play nicely.   Really good beer for an average style.
On tap at Harrys Hofbrau. Subdued malt and floral hops. Slightly hazy golden-amber with full white head. Flavor is citrus and pine. Moderate stong bitterness with a semi-dry finish.

12oz bottle. Bottled on Dec. 9, 2013. Pours a murky brown/amber hue, with partials, and a light khaki colored head. Very faint aromas of malt bread, caramel, and herbal hops when cold. Weak aroma. As promised though, a flood of hops fill the mouth. Flavors of pine and citrus rind dominate, with a good amount of lingering bitterness on the palate. Like chewing on marijuana. It definitely relieved my hop itch, though aroma was a big disappointment for the price. If your craving bitter hops in your mouth, this is worth trying... Good hoppy palate. Though if your looking for the complete package, with amazing hop aromatics, this beer is a pass. 

--- tasted while on a long journey to understand the world around me...
12 ounce bottle. Hoppy with pine and citrus notes. Body is dark like an amber. Malt build there in the background. Slight fruit finish.

The Sampler, tap: Pours amber with a whitish head. Aroma is citrus, earthy hops, and some pine. Taste is pretty much the same... plenty of earthiness... very Danish in that way. Citrus is subdued and sort of melded into the other hop flavors. Quite bitter. I think we have come to the point where there is no difference between an IPA and an amber. Honestly, who could tell the difference.
Draft. Pours medium brown with lacing head. Nice hop aroma with some nice pine and citrus notes. Medium body, with a nice malty backbone. Nice.

Comes out of the tap an opaque coffee brown with Avery thick tan head. A amber ale? Aroma is not strong but malty with a hint of caramel. Flavor is far better than what the aroma promises, malty and hoppy with firm caramel, earthy and nutty notes. Firm mouthfeel is quite lively and fizzy. Flood your palate with this one.

Pours murky amber with a beige head. The aroma has mushy toasty malt, baked bread, dry caramel, floral / perfume-like hops and some tropical fruit. It has a medium rough body with some minor abrasive carbonation. The flavor starts out with piny, floral and citrusy hops bursting out. There is also a good amount of dry toasted malt that comes off like dark baked bread that balances off the assertive hoppiness. The finish has resiny citrusy hops and dark bread sticking to the tongue and mouth. Really nicely done.

Tap. Amber body with a creamy and rocky tan head and awesome lacing. Light pine aroma. The flavor is grapefruit and pine with some earthy dank. Juicy and yet lightly resinous. The palate is bitter and quenching.

A: Reddish/Brown Hue, Passes Mild Light, Off White Head, Decent Lacing

S: Caramel, Black Bread, Mildly Piney

T: Piney, Bready, Mild Coffee, Mild Caramel

M: Decent Carbonation, Medium Bodied, Mildly Drying, Mildly Bitter

Overall, a nice hoppy brown ale with a mild touch of sweetness, well balanced

A murky dark amber ale with a thin brown head. In aroma, a nice biscuit malt with light vinous notes, close to a barley wine, with musky floral hops, very nice. In mouth, a sweet caramel vinous malt with grassy and floral hops, light orange pulp and mint...veering into barley wine territory, with nice treacles.

Une bière ambrée bouetteuse avec une arôme de céréales et de caramel principalement, pas la bombe houblonnée auquel je mattendais. Des notes de houblons verts se faufilent mais jai pas bien saisi sa personnalité, mes attentes mont peut-être corrompues.
Soft caramel aromas move quickly to pencil eraser cocoas soft bitterness. Lots of oxidative notes. Soft astringency. Rust and apple pie. Evening tang. Dark brown and cloudy. Not sure whats up here.

Bottle shared by Tmoney99 (Sept. 12). Pours a hazy brown amber color with a medium sized beige head. The aroma and flavor are herbal, earthy, some fruity character, peel, toasted caramel. Finish has some grassy bitterness. Probably should have some more hop pop if you are going to call it Hop Flood.

Interesting. Pours murky brown and initially gushed after opening. Huge head that takes forever to dissipate and clumpy many finger beige lacing. Nose is candi sugar and rubber bands. Notes of candi sugar, some caramel, some raisin, resin. Taste is medium sweet and med/heavy bitterness that lasts a bit. Creamy body with an acidic bite and well carbonated.

Aroma is strong tropical fruit/kiwi, mild/medium sweetness and spices. The flavor is spicy yeast, tropical fruit, citrus, mild grapefruit/hop resin notes, malts, mild sweetness/sugar and a tangy/slightly sweet finish. One of the better Evil Twin offerings Ive had.

A murky dark amber ale with a thin brown head. In aroma, a nice biscuit malt with light vinous notes, close to a barley wine, with musky floral hops, very nice. In mouth, a sweet caramel vinous malt with grassy and floral hops, light orange pulp and mint...veering into barley wine territory, with nice treacles.
Bottle shared by adnielsen. Pours a cloudy dirty red. Caramel shines through for sure, some hops as well. Sweeter than anticipated, decent hops on the tongue.

Bottle in Minneapolis picked up in KC. Pours a bit hazy reddish brown appearance with a brown head. Chocolate, light caramel, somewhat piney, fairly spicy, decently fresh aroma. A little chewy, toffee, brown sugar, caramel, somewhat piney/woody hoppy flavor. Not super fresh but not bad.

A very hoppy amber.  Okay very malty.  Not sweet ends. It's ok
Nothing special.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle supplied by UDBeernut in not so surprising visit.  Barleywine nose.  Body of Newt.  Malt malt hops.  Elastic body. Mellow and understated. Make me wanna dance like Art.

Bottle split with some doucher. Pours amber with a supple tan head. Nose is of major malt, caramel, slight nod to pine. Taste follows this mold with a body that is full. To me, this, is a beer that is like SN Bigfoot Light.

Bottle at Borefts 2012 - Bodegraven. Pours cloudy amber with a creamy beige head. Rich pine and caramel in the nose. Big sweet flavor with sticky, piney hops, ripe fruit, dry caramel. Medium bodied with fine to average carbonation. Sturdy resinous finish with loads more pine, ripe berries, further caramel. Pretty nice amber ale.

Dark amber/cider color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of toasted caramel malt, pine hops, & citrus; Flavor of slight roasted malt, caramel, spicy hops, some fruit, and citrus; Finish is fairly bitter; Nicely balanced; Pretty good.

Bottle. Amber pour with a white head. Unbalanced with bitter medicinal hops running the show. Decent body and carbonation. A little on the dry and in my opinion in need of a more substantial malt backbone.

66 cl. bottle, brewed by Westbrook Brewing. Dark, amber colour with a huge, dense lightly tan head. Fruity aroma with citrus, pines, grapefruit and, floral hops. Rich caramel and chocolate malts. Taste is bitter. Medium body, creamy texture. Finishes bitter with citrus fruits, resins and rich malts. Very nice amber.

UPDATED: JUN 3, 2013 Poured cloudy, dark caramel brown with a super tall head that would not fall.  Left craggy rocky lace.  Frothy and sticky.  Nose is pine and grapefruit, deep caramel malt, brown sugar and as it warms some nuts and pear.  Nose is delightfully sweet and tempting. Taste is piney, nutty, caramel, dry toast.  Pear and fruits all sensualize the perfect toasted sugar and bitter that caress the palate in the finish. A little alcohol   and char. Ends dry with a touch of oily resin  and a lasting sweetness that stays right under the bitter.  This was a real treat.

UPDATED: SEP 29, 2015 Color: dark brown beer with medium carbonation and medium ivory head. Smell: hops, spices, malt, barley, caramel. Taste: strong taste of hops with nice malt. Amazing complexity. Aftertaste: hops, wet bitterness, and malt.
-----
Bottle at Six Roses, Lille - FR. Color: clear dark amber beer with small carbonation and small ivory head. Smell: hoppy, pines, resin, and caramel domination. Grassy notes. Taste: hit of hops resin. Very nice hoppy taste, more resin and grass domination than fruits and flowers. Very interesting. Aftertaste: hops wrecker on mouth. Very intensive and high bitterness. Oily finish sensation.

Pours a deep red with a big loose-ish head and lots of lacing on the glass. 

The aroma has lots of rich caramel & a light roastiness... Kind of herbal and citrusy but not especially hop focused in the nose, much more about big malt character. 

The flavor is not as sweet as it smells, its plenty bitter, and has some nice piney hop flavor. The malt is pretty dominant here as well, some light chocolate,  some nice caramel... but not really in an annoying or over sweet kind of way. 

The palate is prickly and overall this is an enjoyable beer.

Dark murky red/brown doby with a rocky light brown head. Strong hoppy aroma with pine, grapefruit, bread, toast, caramel, brown sugar. Full body, ideal carbonation. Great heavy bitter flavour with lots of pine, grapefruit, as well as brown sugar, peach and a hint of chocolate in the sweet undertone. Great.
May 2012. Pours copper color form the bottle with a tan head. Aromas are resin, caramel, spice and grapefruit. The finish has a little sweetness blended in with the bitter tones.
Hazy amber colour. Roasted caramel, slight hop aroma. Malty caramel taste, some hops. Was expecting more hops, maybe the bottle i tasted was old, and the hop flavour/aroma deteriorated

Bomber from Antioch Fine Wine. Pours a hazy orangey-brown with a tan head. Huge bubbles in the top made for an interesting trip down the glass - looked like pancake batter needing to be flipped. Aroma is of kick-you-in-the-face hops; floral, citrusy, piney, herbal hops. Also, brown sugar and some caramel and licorice. More of an overdone, overlayered, "american strong ale" smell than a necessarily pleasant one. Taste is of sweet fruits, caramel malts, bitter citrus fruits, tangy spicyness and some earthy pine ... with a brown sugar layer over everything. Sticky and bittersweet. Fairly thick and certainly chewy. Interesting blend of tastes; showing components of an ipa, an american strong ale and a scotch ale. Some alcohol presence, although it is not a key part. Finishes long and bittersweet. Evil Twin seems to like complexity, and have done it again. Probably would not categorize as an amber - would go more american strong. Enjoyable!

In short: A roasted, somewhat resinous and strangely meaty burgundy ale.  Something wrong here
How: Bottle 22oz, consumed a few weeks after purchase, as fresh as I Evil Twin can be in North-America.
The look: Cloudy burgundy body topped by a medium beige head with medium retention.
In long: Nose has big toasted sweet barley, some hops resin.  Taste is sweet toasted barley, burnt straws, hard candies, light notes of nutmeg, tree sap, resinous hops.  Strong bitterness coming from the resin and roast.  Also, the whole time I was drinking the beer I had an annoying roasted meaty sensation that was somewhat reminiscent of a BBQed red meat, not something Im looking for in a beer.  This was a very tasty beer but this one didnt work for me at all.  Not sure if I got a mistreated bottle but this beer was just wrong.  At the end I drank the whole bottle but I was very tempted to drain pour some of it.  Meh I rarely open a beer I dont intend to finish and I rarely start writing a rating I dont intend fini
@BBF12. Pours copper with a beige head. Aroma is roasted caramel, heavu citrus, grapefruit and peach. Flavour is roasted caramel, heavy citrus, grapefruit and light peach.
Light cola color, huge head, fragrance of a belgian but no bite, malty roasted flavors with just enough hops to make a great finish.

[Bottle] Pours deep brownish amber with a small beige head. Aroma is very nice--brown sugar, raisin, prune, and big nuttiness. Quite a bit of bitterness in the taste, nuttiness again (hazelnut), toasted malt, some underlying juicy grapefruit, and another fruit I cant peg. I like it.  Good mouthfeel, long finish. Overall, this is an outstanding amber, and all around a very enjoyable beer.
Dampolla. Color marró clar, escuma també. Aroma de llùpol, tocs de regalèssia i fins i tot alguns tocs torrats. El sabor és amarg, lleugerament picant. Bona cervesa però podria ser millor.

BBF 12
they ran out of everything they brought, so they rushed to the store and opened bottles or something like that...
looks amber, very small foam, taste is verry hoppy oin the bitter end. yet nothing extreme here...
Pours an amber red, subtle aroma of malt and slight hop. Taste is more malty with a slight bitterness. Nothing special.
roasty, cooked vegetables, brown, cloudy, cloudy, minimal head, heavy cloying sweetness, very bitter, medium sourness, full body, thick feel, average carbonation, bitter,
From a 22 oz bottle shared at home.  Pours a cloudy amber with an off white head.  Nutty aroma.  Flavors of chocolate, toasted  malt and hops.  Slightly bitter finish.

Bottle. Poured a hazy brown with a quick tan head that left a light lace. Aroma of roasted malt, fruit, and a hop background. The flavor found caramel, chocolate, roast, and a hop backing. Medium body that initially had a roast aftertaste that turned to a mild hop aftertaste as it warmed.

Bottle. Pours murky brown with thick, frothy beige head; good retention and lacing. Aroma is cookie and caramel malts, dates, floral hops, brown sugar, raisins, and light vanilla. Flavor is balanced sweet malts and hops (medium bitterness) with some supporting dark fruit esters and light woody notes; dry, lightly hoppy finish. Medium body and low carbonation.

Bottle.  Pours hazy to cloudy dark amber with a large, frothy and pillowy tan head, long retention with excellent lacing.  Aroma is citrus, pine, and resin fresh hops with cracker and meal malt and apricot fruity esters.  Flavor is malty sweetness with orange hops and light bitterness, apricot and passion fruit esters with a dry finish.  Medium body and carbonation.

Bottle at home. Pours brown with a huge beige head. The aroma is hops, caramel, fruit and toasted malt. The flavour is toasted malty with citric hoppy notes. Bread, light chocolate and biscuits. Great. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

It pours a dark cloudy brown .A foamy one inch off-white head forms and slowly dies to a film coating the top of the pint. Sticky lacing clings  around the sides of the nonic. The smell has the hops up front with some light caramel and nuts coming more so in as the beer warms. The taste takes all of the previously mentioned flavors and adds a nice clean sweetness with a tinge of alcohol. The mouthfeel is about a medium with a nice smooth creaminess surrounding the mouth and tongue. This is moderately drinkable. Overall, I like this and would come back to it.

A - Cloudy amber-brown, finger of frothy tannish head. Fades fairly slowly.

S - Pine and grapefruit hops, sweet caramel malts, brown sugar, nuttiness, a touch of fruity yeast.

T - Grapefruit, pine, and grassy hops, some lightly resiny bitterness, sweet caramel and lightly bready malts, brown sugar.

M - Medium bodied moderate carbonation. Smooth, dry, bitter, sweet finish.

D - Nicely balanced. Good hoppy brown ale.

Reddish brown colour, beige head. Aroma of hops, resin, hay, malts, caramel, light fruity aromas and hops. Light sweet flavour, bitter, honey. Hoppy bitter finish, light honey, apricot.
(From 66cL bottle @ Colins 2nd Tuesday Tasting @ De Molen)

Bottle. Clear amber, tanned head. Very good aroma of hops, hints of licorice and even some roasted touches. Flavor is bitter, spiced but does not live up to the smell. Decent brew, flavor could be better.

sample at the monthly molen Tuesday tasting 
thin off white creamy head.  hazy amber pour.  choppy bitterness.
Dark amber, hazy, beige head. Fruity hop aroma. Taste is hops, something medicinal, spicy. Bitter and quiet dry with a nice fruity sweetness.

Amber color...hopy aromas.
Malt, caramel with a dry bitter finish.
Very pleasant beer

Botella.Presencia de color cobre y espuma beige poco persistente. Aroma a lupulo y caramelo. Sabor dulce y maltoso y pronto pasa a notas resinosas, recordando a las barleywine, buena integracion de alcohol y carbonatacion media baja.
Draft at coles, buffalo. Amber brown pour. Piney hops and caramal maltiness, brown sugar notes in both the aroma and flavor. Hops stand out, finally an amber beer that Ill go back to
Pours dark browm,  maybe black..  Brown head..hoppy malty aroma... Taste is brown sugar..toast, tiny hints of black licorice.oatmeat..super tasty..  Love it
Smells hoppy with a lot of syrupy malt aro,a. Pours reddish with really good lacing, some head.  lots of malt for the style. Taste is a little bitter. Pretty low carbonation. On tap at coles.

Loads of grassy hops mixed with dark malts in the background. Pretty bitter.

Sample at Borefts Beer Festival 2012. Pours a clear and dark brown beer with an offwhite head. The aroma is malt, caramel and hops with tropical fruit and citrus. The flavor follows the nose. The palate is bitterness. Overall a good beer.

Appearance is probably my favorite part of the beer... nice reddish brown pour with an almost pinkish head. Good hop smell initially but the roasty malt comes through as well as it opens up. Smells like Stone SSR. Roasty bread and subtle hops, mostly caramel malts. Decent stuff.

Location: .5 L bottle from State Line, 11/9/12


Aroma: It has a big, dense hop nose, grapefruit/citrus, and some sweet caramel

Appearance: Pours a cloudy dark amber color with a foamy beige head and medium-heavy lace

Flavor: The taste starts fairly sweet, lot of grapefruit,  and it becomes heavily bitter in the end palate

Palate: The body is medium-full, with a fairly sticky and dense feel, soft carbonation, and heavy dry finish

Overall Impression: 
This is one is big and dense.  It drinks nicely even though it feels pretty thick.  I liked it.  Big, dense, sweet, and bitter.  This one is a tasty offering.

Location/Date:Bottle on November 9th,2012.
Appearance:Pours a brown with hints of red.
Aroma:aroma of caramel, boozy.
Taste: Medium light bitterness, caramel.
Palate:Medium light.
Summary: interesting beer.  Amber qualities but at times seems almost bordering on a barley wine.

Amber color with a lacing of off white head. Aroma is sticky, piney hops. Flavor is strong pine hops, very sticky with a nice malt back and a surprisingly clean finish. It might be the first overhopped amber Ive had and its pretty well done.

Nice dark red haze beer with tan head. Aroma of peach and lime. Dark toasty toffee taste with warmth from the alcohol. Quite bitter and dry. Medium to full bodied. Very nice. Good autumn ipa.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Dark brown ale, roasty malt flavor. Not excessively hopped but nicely smooth. Delicious but not one of Evil Twins best.
Boreft Beer Festival 2012. Hazy dark copper with a small off-white head. Malty aroma of toffee and biscuit with a touch of citrus hops. Dry, toffee-malty flavour with citrus and peach
Bottle @ tasting. Aroma is deep bread, rye, chocolate, roast and some hoppy notes. Flavour is deep bready rye, strong bitter hops, roasty notes and more.

Bottle @ home. Clear dark amber pour, foamy off-white head. Aroma full of floral hops, tea, plants and some caramel. Flavor is mostly bitter, quite some tea and loads of hops. Nice brew, a bit bitter.

UPDATED: FEB 28, 2013 Bomber from Capones.  Pours very turbid burnt sienna toward ruby with 3-finger fluffy off-white head that laces copiously.  Nose is intense piney resiny hops, with a substantial caramel malt bill, plus spicy cinnamonny tangerine and pineapple notes.  On the repour, the head takes an odd but firm shape.  The flavor is caramel malty...very malty and on the sweet side, then the big piney tangeriney hops hit the palate and balance things out nicely.  The mouthfeel is dense, hefty, and very complex, and finishes like a dense hoppy barleywine with more smoothness than, say, something like Hog Heaven.  This beer is solid.
On tap at Elizabeth Station. Pours a dark mahogany brown with light head. Hoppy pine and citrus aroma. Flavors of grapefruit, caramel, and roasted malts. A nice mix.
Very hoppy, to the point where it tasted like a whiskey. Intriguing name, color and aroma, but definitely not my palate.

With a name like  Hop Flood, youd never expect the color this beer shows when poured; a deep muddy amber-brown!  Youd also never expect to find suspended colloidal-like yeast "asteroids" floating in space!  Now the pond-scum, whipped cream head covers the secrets of this marvelous, unique brew! The nose is redolent of skunky hops; good, I like this...but butterscotch notes also ensue...the taste is a symphony of wonderment; the mouthfeel insanely perfect!  Layer upon layer of multideminsional flavors ebb and flow like a great symphonic masterpiece!  This is a thinking mans brew. The hop component of this beer reminds me a lot of last years Stone black IPA...what a cool beer; digging this!
Nice hop aroma that was not too strong. A toffee and nutty malt taste with just the right amount of bitter. An intro IPA.

Bottle sample at the Evil Twin tasting at Blacklick Wine & Spirits on 10/4/12. Clear brown pour with a huge tan head. Malty nose with notes of toffee, licorice, tobacco and earthy hops. Malty flavor with toffee and roast before a piney hop finish.

Bottle sample @ Borefts 2012. The pours deep amber with a massive off-white head. The nose is of strawberry, malty fruit punch. A bit gritty and grassy. The taste is more strawberry syrup, brash bitter hop, lightly herbal. Bitter finish. Medium body. Pretty good!

Bottle. Heavy malt aromas of roasted and caramel, moderate to heavy cooked grapefruit and orange juice, light soap for the yeast with wood, date and other dark dried fruits in the background. Head is average to large, between frothy and creamy, lightl beige with fair thin lacing and is mostly lasting. Color is murky mahogany. Flavor starts moderately acidic and finishes moderately to heavily bitter. Palate is medium, dry with a lively carbonation and has a very dry finish. This Amber Ale has an almost barley wine-like aroma, and the flavor is completely devoid of sweetness. The spooge at the bottom muddies it up and adds a bit of funkiness. If youre an IBU fan this one is for you.

Sample at SBWF 2012.

Dark brown with a small head. Aroma and taste of fruit, nuts, malt and some toffee. RIP to all the bottles that didnt make it.

UPDATED: DEC 27, 2012 Bottled. Pours hazy amber with a large off-white head. Nose of citrus fruits and caramel. Sweet flavor of again citrus especially grape fruit and caramel.. Medium bodied, oily texture and soft carbonation. End up more dry and solod bitter. Quite nice.★★★★

22oz bottle In a tulip.  Pours ruby/brown with a fluffy, tan head. Aroma strong of citrusy hops, plus some caramel and bread like malts to balance it out.  Flavor the same, with a lot of hops.  Average texture.  A good beer.

1/2 liter bottle- pours a very dense orange rust color with off white creamy head.   No bottle date but says use by 2014 (long enough to sail to India from Copenhagen, I guess).  This is a very earthy, yeasty IPA with a strong hop presence and a bitter finish. I would love to have one of these fresh from the tap in Denmark.  I like my IPAs complex and unfiltered, and this takes it to the limit.  A bit too roasty for my taste but a complex and very chewy offering. A pint of this could be a meal.

Bottle sampled @ Borefts 2012. Dark brown with a mocha head. Smells of sharp pine, earthly hops blended with a tad lesser sweet caramel malts. Very bitter pine resin, yeast flavours, cut slightly by some caramel malts, some earthiness as well, lightly muddled, medium bodied. Ok but bit lacking compared to other hoppy beers - expect a bit more / different with a beer called Hop Flood.

UPDATED: DEC 11, 2012 Copper body and light creamy tan head. Amber with barley wine aspirations. Pine and resin hops. Taste also has a whole lot of bitterness to compensate the caramel. (On tap at Borefts 2012)

Bottle at Borefts. Cloudy dark brown pour, thin tan head. As the name suggests this beer is all about the hops. Big malty spicy aroma with an all spicy dry hop peppery flavour. The first mouthful was somewhat of a shock, but it rapidly grew on me and I really appreciated the spiciness of this ale towards the end. I will look it up on my next visit to CPH.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a deep rusty brown color with a finger of off white foam that settles quickly. On the nose its alot of earthy malt with hints of citrus and pine. On the palate this beer has big malty flavor but not so much sweetness... a rich black tea earthy bordering on graham cracker towards the bitter finish makes a great base for big bitter hop notes of pine, citrus and grapefruit !
Pours a medium to dark bbrown with orange hew. Nose is brown malt, melln rind.first sip is nice piney,passion fruit, juicy friuts finish is mild lingering bitterness.
Nutty, dried leaves aroma. Murky brown, medium yellow head, good lacing. Flavor is dried leaves, walnut, and malt bitterness. Bitter walnut lingers.

Bottle shared by Butters. Thanks! Pours a murky brown color with a medium sized frothy head. Decent head retention. Aroma of big resin and herbal hops with toffee malts. The taste is herbal and resin hops. Faint caramel malts. Lingering bitterness. Thin-medium bodied. Decent.
Sampled at Dans after Top of the Hops tasting.  Clear amber pour with good ring of khaki head. Sweet but hoppy bitter.  Honey.  Good.

September 18, 2012 - on draught at Blue Monk.  Murky reddish-brown with a smallish creamy/foamy tan head.  Smells like a not-boozy American barley wine - tons of dry leafy resin bitterness, some alcohol; very malty, but not really sweet, maybe a hint of cocoa powder in there;  dry (7+).  Taste follows, even more bitter, maybe a little lactic sourness.  Thick, solidly carbonated, finishes dry and leafy, and the bitterness doesnt ramp up, it fades a bit - easy to drink.

Bottle. Poured clear dark hazy amber hue with medium frothy white head that lasted with good lacing. Medium to heavy aroma of earthy hops and malt. Medium to full body with a slick texture and soft carbonation. Well balanced flavor of malt and earthy hops with a medium to heavy bittersweet finish of moderate duration. Good drinkable brew.

Pours deep amber/chestnut with a medium tan head.  Aroma caramel and fruit with some orange and tea notes.  Flavor is very earthy and bitter...mild coffee, tea, grapefruit, and pine...very earthy.  Mouthfeel is medium and silky with a very earthy, bitter finish...lt coffee and dry.

Bottle to snifter (thanks tmoney99). Looks solid; a cloudy amber with thin beige lacing. Smells and tastes well-sweet and a little golly. Good, but Id like to see a little more hops, given its name.

22 oz. bottle, pours a dark amber with a medium beige head. Aroma is a mix of both potent caramel malts and a resinous hop blast, with some notes of dark fruit and brown sugar as well  very inviting nose. Flavour is very deep and robust, with loads of dry caramel malts, lots of resinous hops, some dark fruits and some earthy notes  finishes very dry and fairly hoppy. Full-bodied and highly flavourful for the style  certainly one of the best amber ales out there.

Bottle from 99. Cloudy brown pour with a short, brief beige head leaving moderate lace. Nose is mostly medium-roast malt, dark fruit and pine hops  like a hoppy barleywine. Medium-heavy body with light, fine carbonation. Mouth feel is smooth and somewhat heavy for an amber. Dark fruit, pine, chocolate, grapefruit, walnuts, dates and toffee. Finish is medium, mostly sweet but with some grapefruit. Quite good, with a great malt profile, but a bit on the dark/heavy side in aromas and the hops are too attenuated after the journey.
Draft at The Pine Box, Seattle. Deep rose amber, tan foamy head. Big worty, boil of hops and oil. Roasty malt. Big sweet pine hops on first sip. Warming malts. Quite tasty, nice bright beer.
Toffee and nut aromas. Nutty malty flavors. Not much in the way hops. Overall not bad but also not very hoppy.

This should be called malt flood. Mahogany body with a thin, off white head. Cola like aromatics and the palate shows both nutty, brown and caramel amber characteristics. A bit of hops on the finish. Extremely high carbonation.

Sample at Ale Wine & Spirits in Powell on 08/30/2012. The beer pours a dark amber color with a medium off-white head that diminishes steadily. Partial rings of lacing on the glass. Aroma of hops, citrus and sweet malt. Medium body with flavors of herbal hops, caramel malt and fruit. The finish is hoppy with some resin and malt in the aftertaste. Above average overall.

Bottle.  Big muddy pour ... deep, dark and woody.  The aroma carries a bit of varnish.  This drinks with a gigantic character ... thick, chewy even.  The woodsy bitterness is the predominate aspect of this brew ... with a thick-as-stone malt backdrop.  Good stuff, worthy.  (#4754, 8/30/2012)
Gedronken bij joes, bruin/rood van kleur, ruikt en smaakt hoppig, bitter, kruidig, zoet caramel, toffee

22oz bottle.  Large beige head atop cloudy dark amber body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, herbal, grapefruit, caramel, light chocolate.  Taste is sweet, caramel/bread, grapefruit, spicy/herbal, some chocolate.  Medium body, some resin, surprisingly drinkable.

Good head, off white, great lacing, dark brown. Sweet hoppy aroma.  A little sweet, nice bitter finish.  Really smooth and very easy to drink.

Thete is so much here to like and nothing to dislike.  My only knock is that it is so over done.

[500ml bottle, courtesy of cgarvieuk] Slightly hazy reddish amber. Piney hop aroma. Nice body for 7%, more caramel on the flavour than the aroma. The trouble is, after a while it becomes sugar and not much else. Needs work on the balance, I think [06072012]

Wow, fantastic beer. A brown pour with khaki head around the edges. The aroma is solid hops, but with a nutty base. The taste follows with warming hops blended wonderfully into a nutty brown ale base. Some bitterness, some hop brightness and pineyness, Medium mouthfeel, and easily drinkin.
Enjoyed this one - its my kind of beer.

Draft at Thirsty monk. Pours brown with an a quarter inch of khaki foam that leaves a slight amount of lacing. Nice hoppiness on the nose that becomes more prominent as it warms. Lots of hops on the tongue with a small hint of roast malt that comes through in the finish. Interesting interpretation of the style.

6 July 2012, bottle at cagarvie's legendary tasting. Light ruby, faintly hazy. Nose is sweet, faint toffee, pine hops. Med body, faintly fizzy. Piney hops, slightly skunky, sweet but bitter finish.

500ml bottle from Ridgewood Wine & Beer, Raleigh. Thick pour, dark orange and creamy looking, quite potent. Malts and tea in the nose, almost like a downshifted Double Bastard. Bottle.  A brownish copper color with a big tan head.  A fruity hop aroma with a nice malt base and finish.  Thanks to Brent for this birthday beer.

(Keg at Craft Beer Co., 26/04/12). Translucent, hazy orange-brown. Light, persisting, off-white/greenish head, good lacing. Light carbonation. Fresh, green hop aroma, slight tropical fruit, tangerine, floral, light toffeeish malt, nice. Medium body, quite frothy on the tongue, slight astringent. A good hoppy, fruity ale, balanced, retaining some of the bitterness youd expect and not cloying with too much sugariness like some american-style IPAs can be.

Keg at CP&K. It pours cloudy amber, with a thick beige head. The nose is resin, caramel sweetness, pine and brown bread. The nose is resin, pine, grapefruit, caramel, brown bread, raisin, currant, raw hop and a touch of metal, with a long, bitter finish. Medium body and fine carbonation. Nice.

Keg at Cask Pub and Kitchen, Pimlico, London. A dark red/amber coloured pour with a medium white head on top. Hoppy, caramel aroma. Tastes hoppy, malty, fruity, slightly sweet with some caramel. Very enjoyable, my first Evil Twin beer.

660 ml bottle - pours deep red amber with a medium persisting egg-shell white head. Subtle aromas of orange peel, grapefruit and chocolate; some vanilla as well. Medium body with medium bitterness and dryness in the end.

50cll bottle shared by Dutchdrebus. Opaque red-amber color, small off-white to beige head that becomes a slight lacing. Smell malts, hops, lightly pine and resin. Taste malts, hops, bitter. Medium body, medium carbo.
